expected_issues.description: Anticholinergic agent (Oxybutynin) in patient with glaucoma - acute angle-closure risk
expected_issues.reasoning: Anticholinergic medications cause pupillary dilation (mydriasis), which can precipitate acute angle-closure glaucoma attack - sudden IOP elevation causing severe eye pain, vision loss, and potential permanent blindness. While patient has open-angle glaucoma (not angle-closure), anticholinergics can still worsen IOP control. Alternative treatments (beta-3 agonists like mirabegron) should be used.
